Analysis.name: Exergaming vs control at the end of treatment: change in attention, processing speed, working memory
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Comment: Participants were randomly assigned to the intervention and control group using generated random numbers. Allocation concealment was not described. There were no baseline differences between groups.

Analysis.name: Exergaming vs control at the end of treatment: change in attention, processing speed, working memory
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Comment: Report of randomisation procedures and allocation concealment. No significant differences between groups at baseline.

Analysis.name: Number of dropouts at follow-up (exergame vs control intervention) for people with mild cognitive impairment (MCI)
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Comment: Participants were randomly assigned to the intervention and control group using generated random numbers. Allocation concealment was not described. There were no baseline differences between groups.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int:
Comment: Blinding was not possible. 

Comment: No information concerning allocation concealment. Blinding participants was not possible.

Comment: There were no deviations from intendent interventions described.

Comment: No ITT analysis was performed. 

Comment: No evidence for this.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Comment: Only ine participant failed to complete the CAMCI assessment due to transportation issues as reported by study authors which is unlikely to have affected the overall result.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo:
Comment: ADL was measured using a validated scale: Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (Owsley et al., 2012). 

Comment: Measurements and timepoints for ADL were the same for exergame and active control group. There was no evidence in the methods to indicate different measurements methods and thresholds. 

Comment: No description concerning blinding of outcome assessors was provided in the paper. 

The outcome measure was the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (Owsley et al., 2012) which is not a patient reported measures. It consists of several items that measure functionality using performance-based tasks (e.g., speed and accuracy across several domains such as grocery shopping, and medication management).

Comment: Used objective data.

Comment: Used objective data.

Comment: No evidence of this.

Comment: No description concerning blinding of outcome assessors was provided in the paper. 

The outcome measure was the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (Owsley et al., 2012) which is not a patient reported measures. It consists of several items that measure functionality using performance-based tasks (e.g., speed and accuracy across several domains such as grocery shopping, and medication management).

Analysis.name: Number of dropouts at follow-up (exergame vs control intervention) for people with mild cognitive impairment (MCI)
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Comment: Randomisation was done by centre but there is no information on the method used. No information about allocation concealment or timing of recruitment. No significant baseline differences between groups except sex, but no indication that there was a problem with the randomisation process or to suggest differential identification or recruitment of participants between groups.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int:
Comment: There was not enough information reported in the paper concerning this.
Comment: There was not enough information reported in the paper concerning this.
Comment: There was not enough information reported in the paper concerning this.
Comment: Analyses excluded trial participants and/or clusters not receiving their intervention.
Comment: At cluster level there were
eight daycare centers (four control centers, four intervention centers);
six nursing homes (three control centers, three intervention centers);

Clusters included an even number of centres for: daycare centres (4/4), nursing homes (3/3). For memory centres there were 2 control centres and four intervention centres. Three of these centres one memory center, one daycare center, one nursing home) did not include any participants. No justification was provided by the authors.
center, one nursing home) did not include any participants. There were significant droup-outs at participant level as well.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support:
Comment: At cluster level there were
eight daycare centers (four control centers, four intervention centers);
six nursing homes (three control centers, three intervention centers);

Clusters included an even number of centres for: daycare centres (4/4), nursing homes (3/3). For memory centres there were 2 control centres and four intervention centres. Three of these centres one memory center, one daycare center, one nursing home) did not include any participants. No justification was provided by the authors.
center, one nursing home) did not include any participants. 
Comment: At participant level there were drop-outs. Drop-outs (N = 4) in the control group are larger vs. exergame group (N = 0) and no justification was provided.
Comment: No sensitivity analysis was reported.
Comment: No information concerning reasons for participant drop-out at follow-up was provided for the exergame and control groups. The number of participant drop-outs in the control group were larger (N = 4) vs the exergame group (N = 0) without any justification of why this has happnened.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo:
Comment: Global cognition was measured using a validated scale: MMSE.
Comment: Outcomes were recorded at 24 weeks.
Comment: No information concerning this.
Comment: Not enough information concerning this was provided.
Comment: The scale used to measure global cognition was MMSE, a well-validated scale results could have been influenced by the knowledge of the intervention received (in case of absence of blinding).
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result:
Comment: We were not able to find a protocol online or any pre-planned data analysis plan. No mention about a protocol was found in the paper.
Comment: MMSE and global cognition was assessed/reported only at follow-up (24 weeks) and not at post-test (12 weeks) without any justification.
Comment: We could not make an informed decision as we did not have enough data to support it.
Overall.bias.support:
The study is judged to be at high risk of bias in at least one domain for this result. 

This was a cluster RCT.  We acknowledge an additional domain related to timing and recruitment of participants. This was assessed as having some concerns because there was not enough information reported in the paper concerning this domain.
